1.title: Whym
1.desc: An app for the procrastinators. We show you an overview of the look and feel of the iPhone app.

2.title: BlackFriday.FM
2.desc: Retro style brand expression delivering black friday news and RSS feeds

3.title: Lately
3.desc: The stem of a brand aimed at frugal fashionistas.

4.title: Culture SJ
4.desc: Designing a poster for a plan to bring a community together with food, music, and fashion.

5.title: Dishcrawl
5.desc: A new take on a fun way to get around town to see your local restaurants.

1.name: Whym
1.desc: Whym was an app built for the non-planners. The professional crastinators, the improvisers, and those who fly by the seat of their pants. Tour companies often end up with a seat or two they can’t fill, so they can list their unsold tickets on the Whym platform, and even enjoy getting some exposure by being on the app.

bio.1: When designing the app, the main focus was finding a simple and elegant way to streamline the ticket purchasing process, as each company has very specific needs and requires different information from their customers to properly reserve a spot. This also proved to be the greatest challenge, but we think we nailed it.
bio.2: We also did some collateral like advertisements and homepage design. The advertisements were used as marketing on Facebook.
bio.3: Whym’s UI was mentioned on the Today Show in 2017 in their “Top Apps of 2017” segment. Randi Zuckerberg (yes… Mark’s sister) showed off our product and called it a 'must have.'

2.name: Culture SJ
2.desc: Culture San José was an initiative to bring the citizens of the multicultural city together and share great food, music, and more. Though this project never came to realization, we’d love to share with you the whimsical and exciting vibes that these prints radiate.

3.name: Dishcrawl
3.desc: Many people who live in big cities can’t explore the entirety of the food selection available. Dishcrawl curated eating experiences that allowed a small group of people to try foods from as many as 4 restaurants in a night.

bio.1: These are proposals for a total overhaul of the UX of the web platform. We brought vibrance and a smooth, capable experience to the brand, focusing on presenting an intuitive and functional interface.
bio.battledishBody: Dishcrawl hosted competitions that pitted chefs against chefs, by category. The winner could claim bragging rights and would get the opportunity to be recognized within and around their community.
bio.tastemakersBody: The tastemaker plan was an idea aimed at getting loyal Dishcrawlers to become part of an exclusive group that enjoyed discounts at restaurants in their area, and to feel prized as a member.

4.name: Lately
4.desc: A logo for a fashion-based lifestyle app aimed at staying with the current trend. Two offered concepts.

5.name: Japan Wifi Buddy
5.desc: JapanWifiBuddy started up as a side business in late-2014. Seeing a need for travelers coming to Japan having difficulties staying connected to the internet affordably, the owner started out slowly accumulating and renting pocket wifi devices to travelers coming in to Japan. After a half-year they decided to start a Shopify store, where the shop continued to grow for another year or so.

bio.1: These are proposals for a total overhaul of the UX of the web platform. We brought vibrance and a smooth, capable experience to the brand, focusing on presenting an intuitive and functional interface.
bio.battledishBody: Dishcrawl hosted competitions that pitted chefs against chefs, by category. The winner could claim bragging rights and would get the opportunity to be recognized within and around their community.
bio.tastemakersBody: The tastemaker plan was an idea aimed at getting loyal Dishcrawlers to become part of an exclusive group that enjoyed discounts at restaurants in their area, and to feel prized as a member.

6.name: Rare Candy
6.desc: Pokémon was a large part of Peter Le's and Amy Kim's lives as kids, as well as that of their friends. They decided to host an art gallery featuring the original 151 pokémon they had grown up with. They acquired the help of their frinds in the Animation/Illustration program at San José State University to hold it for a good cause.

bio.1: These are proposals for a total overhaul of the UX of the web platform. We brought vibrance and a smooth, capable experience to the brand, focusing on presenting an intuitive and functional interface.

1.title: ウィーム
1.desc: Whym（ウィーム）はかっこいい案内景観を紹介して楽しめ

2.title: ブラックフライデー
2.desc: ブラックフライデーのニュースとRSSフィードを配信するレトロなスタイルのブランド表現

3.title: レイトリー
3.desc: 質素なファッショニスタを目指したブランドの原点。

4.title: カルチャーSJ
4.desc: フード、音楽、ファッションとコミュニティを結びつける計画のポスターをデザインする。

5.title: ディシュクロール
5.sub: イメージ変え, UXデザイン, ブランド
5.desc: A new take on a fun way to get around town to see your local restaurants.

1.name: Whym
1.desc: Whym（ウィム）は、非プランナー向けに構築されたアプリでした。 プロのクラスティネーター、即興演奏者、ズボンの座席で飛行する人々。 ツアー会社はしばしば席を埋めることができないので、Whymプラットフォームで売れ残りチケットをリストアップしたり、アプリに参加して露出を楽しんだりすることもできます。

bio.1: アプリを設計する際の主な焦点は、チケット購入プロセスを合理化するためのシンプルでエレガントな方法を見つけることでした。各会社には非常に具体的なニーズがあり、適切にスポットを予約するには顧客からの異なる情報が必要です。 これも最大の課題であることが判明しましたが、我々はそれを打ち出したと思います。
bio.2: また、広告やホームページのデザインなどの担保も行いました。 広告はFacebookのマーケティングとして使用されました。
bio.3: WhymのUIは、2017年のToday Showの「2017年のトップアプリ」セグメントで取り上げられました。 Randi Zuckerberg（そう...マークの妹）は私たちの製品を披露し、「必須」と呼びました。

2.name: Culture SJ
2.desc: 「カルチャー・サンホセ」は、多文化都市の市民を結び付け、素晴らしい食べ物、音楽などを共有するための概念でした。 このプロジェクトは実現しませんでしたが、これらのプリントが放つ気まぐれで刺激的な雰囲気を皆さんと共有したいと思いますね。

3.name: Dishcrawl
3.desc: 大都市に住んでいる多くの人々は、ある食品の選択のすべてを探求することはできません。 ディッシュクロールは、小さなグループが一晩で最大4軒のレストランの料理を試すことができる食事体験をキュレーションしました。

bio.1: これらは、WebプラットフォームのUXの全面的なオーバーホールの提案です。 直感的で機能的なインターフェースの提示に焦点を当て、活気とスムーズで有能な体験をブランドにもたらしました。
bio.battledishBody: ディッシュクロールは、カテゴリー別にシェフとシェフを競うコンテストを開催しました。勝者は自慢できる権利をゲットし、コミュニティ内外で認知される機会を得ます。
bio.tastemakersBody: テイストメーカーの計画は、忠実なディッシュクローラーを、その地域のレストランで割引を享受する排他的なグループに参加させ、メンバーとして高く評価されることを目指したアイデアでした。

4.name: Lately
4.desc: 現在のトレンドにとどまることを目的としたファッションベースのライフスタイルアプリのロゴ。 2つのコンセプトが提供されました。

5.name: Japan Wifi Buddy
5.desc: Pokémon!! was a large part of Peter Le's and Amy Kim's lives as kids, as well as that of their friends. They decided to host an art gallery featuring the original 151 pokémon they had grown up with. They acquired the help of their frinds in the Animation/Illustration program at San José State University to hold it for a good cause.

bio.1: These are proposals for a total overhaul of the UX of the web platform. We brought vibrance and a smooth, capable experience to the brand, focusing on presenting an intuitive and functional interface.

bio.tastemakersBody: The tastemaker plan was an idea aimed at getting loyal Dishcrawlers to become part of an exclusive group that enjoyed discounts at restaurants in their area, and to feel prized as a member.

study.body:
Intro (Intro page?) JapanWifiBuddy began as a side business in late-2014. Seeing a need for travelers coming to Japan having difficulties staying connected to the internet affordably, the owner started out slowly accumulating and renting pocket wifi devices to travelers coming in to Japan. After a half-year they decided to start a Shopify store, where the shop continued to grow for another year or so. Shopify’s guided and railed system proved to be a good place to start, but JWB’s administrative needs grew with their customer base.
Without methods for holding deposits from clients, or charging clients who damaged devices (among other specific needs), it became clear that a new system was necessary. Shopify is designed to run e-commerce for selling one-off products—JWB is a system requiring recirculation of rented products needed a tailored solution. BrightPath teamed up with x47d to build up an entirely custom client-and-device management system which comfortably overcame these difficulties, allowing for breathing room and growth in various other aspects. Sine our implementation of our business solution, JWB saw growth of over 400%. Case Study As a growing rental company, managing the constantly circulating devices traveling around the world became a challenge after about 100 units. Not only tracking their location, but also accurately tracking lifespan, rental history, usage rates, profit rates (after deducting lease expenses) and other such minutiae. Our solution was a booking system that allows clients to determine available for their desired dates, and allows for a smooth and snappy ordering process. This system also secures a more smooth inventory flow, avoiding superfluous leasing fees while also having sufficient supply for peak seasons. Keeping track of various clients’ needs, rental history, personal information and payment data is also crucial for thorough service and record keeping. The previous system on Shopify provided basic information, but JWB needs to track much more minute and detailed information, in a many-to-many relationship fashion. We also included Stripe for more intricate and able charging methods such as charging for lost or damaged routers. JWB also has numerous long-term renters who request to pay monthly rather than up-front, which we accommodated. Inventory forecasting is invaluable for travel-related businesses subject to seasonality. We built an inventory availability forecasting system for JWB, allowing them to see how many units of each device are currently available for rent at any date in the future. If they see a peak season approaching with low availability, they can increase the amount of stock on hand to prepare and maximize profitability. One of the most complex and intricate difficulties JWB faces is managing all of the shipping locations and their work hours. Their clients arrive at any number of airports, where they’re able to pick up their WifiBuddy at one of numerous shipping offices. All of these offices have different hours of availability and require different fees for usage as well. We’ve built a robust logic system that takes in the client’s flight information, arrival times and terminal information, then filters it through the shipping logic, which part of the smooth 3-step ordering process we’ve put together. If the client will be able to pick the package up at the free shipping location, it will prioritize that option, but in many cases for later flights or overnight flights, a shipping upgrade is required. In this case the system charges the client the appropriate upgrade fee and informs the shipping staff which specific office to ship to. Once ordering is complete, the system automatically emails a map of the correct terminal and pickup location to the client, and the staff apply the tracking number and such for the client. This process alone saves WifiBuddy significant amounts of research, client back-and-forth and communication mishaps on every single order. We integrated a super-rapid spreadsheet-based pricing editor which allows the managers to change every single parameter within seconds. This allows them to capitalize on seasonality and demand. We’ve also built in an insurance system for JapanWifiBuddy which gives clients peace-of-mind to avoid damage fees, and also provides some stability for JapanWifiBuddy. The insurance fee is based on the length of the rental, commensurate with the amount of risk of damaging or losing the device. “You can’t improve what you can’t measure.” Words to live by for any entrepreneur or manager. Seeing JapanWifiBuddy’s needs, we decided to put together a robust reporting system. All fields are viewable by day, month or year, and some are also viewable as “All time”. We can expand data tracking if necessary, but some of the features they’ve requested us to display are the following: -Full income (by device/area), expense, profit reporting. -Device revenue charts showing cost, revenue, profit for each device. -Website visits, conversion rates, referrers, browser/device types. -Feeler report and functionality for determining what types of new products to launch. -Order data - average rental length, average rental price, insurance inclusion percentage, average rentals in device life, lifetime revenue, etc. -Deposits in-hand Additional on-request functionality we’ve added for ease-of-management include -Admin/user management for control panels. -Blackout date management for holiday periods or team traveling periods. -Editable notification bar for marketing or sales on the top of the front page. Abhishek’s site : http://www.x47d.com/showcase/japanwifibuddy
